etymology.description: phonetic 卯(卯) (mǎo, "fourth earthly branch") + semantic 金(金) (jīn, "metal") + semantic 刂(刀) (dāo, "knife") = cutting metal -> to kill
etymology.interpretation: The character 劉(劉) (liú, "to kill") combines the notion of cutting or slicing, represented by the knife and metal components, with the phonetic element 卯(卯) (mǎo). This suggests a historical context where metal and knives were associated with killing or cutting.

examples.chinese: 他劉了叛徒(他劉了叛徒)。
将军劉敌于阵前(將軍劉敵於陣前)，士兵肃然起敬(士兵肅然起敬)。
examples.pinyin: Jiāngjūn liú dí yú zhèn qián, shìbīng sùrán qǐ jìng.
examples.english: The general killed the enemy before the battle, and the soldiers were filled with awe.

examples.chinese: 武将劉叛贼于营中(武將劉叛賊於營中)，国家恢复太平(國家恢復太平)。
examples.pinyin: Wǔjiàng liú pàn zéi yú yíng zhōng, guójiā huīfù tàipíng.
examples.english: The general killed the traitors in the camp, and the nation regained peace.
